Question 1 An ideal low pass filter has frequency response given by [latex]
H(j \omega)= \begin{cases}1, & |\omega| \leq 200 \pi \\ 0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}
[/latex] Let [latex]h(t)[/latex] be its time domain representation. Then 
[latex]h(0)=[/latex] ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).

Question 2 The continuous-time unit impulse signal is applied as an input to a continuous-time linear timeinvariant system [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex]. The output is observed to be the continuous-time unit step signal [latex]u(t)[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: Step 1: Given that the output of system [latex] \mathcal{S} [/latex] for an input [latex] \delta(t) [/latex] (unit impulse) is [latex] u(t) [/latex] (unit step), So, the impulse response of the system is: [latex] h(t) = u(t) [/latex] Step 2: A system is Bounded Input Bounded Output (BIBO) stable if its impulse response is absolutely integrable: [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |h(t)| dt < \infty [/latex] Here, [latex] h(t) = u(t) [/latex], so: [latex] \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |u(t)| dt = \int_{0}^{\infty} 1 , dt = \infty [/latex] Hence, the system is not BIBO stable. Step 3: If a system is not BIBO stable, then there exists at least one bounded input that will produce an unbounded output. Final Answer: (B) It is possible to find a bounded input signal which when applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in an unbounded output signal.

options.A: very bounded input signal applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in a bounded output signal.
options.B: It is possible to find a bounded input signal which when applied to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] results in an unbounded output signal.
options.C: On applying any input signal to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex], the output signal is always bounded.
options.D: On applying any input signal to [latex]\mathbf{S}[/latex] the output signal is always unbounded.

Then [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} y(t) d t[/latex] is

Question 4 A continuous time periodic signal [latex]{x}({t})[/latex] is [latex]x(t)=1+2 \cos 2 \pi t+2 \cos 4 \pi t+2 \cos 6 \pi t[/latex]. If [latex]T[/latex] is the period of [latex]x(t)[/latex], then [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T}| x(t)| ^{2} dt=[/latex] _________  (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Step 1: Find the period [latex]T[/latex] The signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] consists of cosine terms with frequencies [latex]2\pi, 4\pi, 6\pi[/latex], which correspond to fundamental frequencies [latex]1 , \text{Hz}, 2 , \text{Hz}, 3 , \text{Hz}[/latex]. The period of the signal [latex]T[/latex] is the least common multiple (LCM) of the periods of these individual cosine terms. The period of [latex]2\pi t[/latex] (1 Hz) is [latex]T_1 = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. The period of [latex]4\pi t[/latex] (2 Hz) is [latex]T_2 = 0.5 , \text{sec}[/latex]. The period of [latex]6\pi t[/latex] (3 Hz) is [latex]T_3 = \frac{1}{3} , \text{sec}[/latex]. The LCM of [latex]T_1, T_2, T_3[/latex] is [latex]T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. Step 2: Calculate [latex] |x(t)|^2 [/latex] The signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is real, so we can calculate [latex]|x(t)|^2[/latex] directly: [latex]|x(t)|^2 = (1 + 2 \cos(2\pi t) + 2 \cos(4\pi t) + 2 \cos(6\pi t))^2[/latex] Expanding the square: [latex]|x(t)|^2 = 1 + 4 \cos(2\pi t) + 4 \cos(4\pi t) + 4 \cos(6\pi t) + 4 \cos^2(2\pi t) + 4 \cos(2\pi t) \cos(4\pi t) + \ldots[/latex] Step 3: Integrate over one period We now need to compute the integral of [latex]|x(t)|^2[/latex] over one period [latex]T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex]. Many of the cross-term integrals, like [latex]\int_0^T \cos(2\pi t) \cos(4\pi t) dt[/latex], will be zero due to the orthogonality property of the cosine functions. For the terms that do not vanish: [latex] \int_0^T 1 , dt = T = 1 , \text{sec}[/latex] [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(2\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2} T = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] (using the identity [latex]\cos^2(x) = \frac{1 + \cos(2x)}{2}[/latex]) Similarly, [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(4\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2}[/latex] and [latex] \int_0^T \cos^2(6\pi t) , dt = \frac{1}{2}[/latex]. Step 4: Sum up the integrals After evaluating the integrals and summing them up, the result of the integral is: [latex] \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt = 1 + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} + 4 \times \frac{1}{2} = 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 7[/latex]. Step 5: Compute the final result Now, we divide by the period [latex]T = 1] sec: [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt = \frac{7}{1} = 7[/latex]. Final Answer: The value of [latex]\frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 , dt[/latex] is closest to 7.

question: Question 5 Consider a continuous-time signal [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t})=-\mathrm{t}^{2}\{\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}+4)-\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}-4)\}[/latex] Where [latex]u(t)[/latex] is the continuous-time unit step function. Let [latex]\delta(\mathrm{t})[/latex] be the continuous-time unit impulse function. The value of [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) \mathrm{dt}[/latex] is
solution: Given: [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) = -\mathrm{t}^2 {\mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}+4) - \mathrm{u}(\mathrm{t}-4)}[/latex] This represents a time-limited signal that exists only between [latex]t = -4[/latex] and [latex]t = 4[/latex]. Outside this interval, [latex]x(t) = 0[/latex]. Also given: We are to compute the value of the integral: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) , \mathrm{dt}[/latex] Step 1: Use the sifting property of the delta function: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \delta(t - t_0) , dt = f(t_0)[/latex] Similarly, [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) \delta(t + 3) , dt = f(-3)[/latex] Step 2: Evaluate [latex]x(-3)[/latex] [latex]x(t) = -t^2 {u(t+4) - u(t-4)}[/latex] At [latex]t = -3[/latex], [latex]u(-3 + 4) = u(1) = 1[/latex] and [latex]u(-3 - 4) = u(-7) = 0[/latex] So, [latex]x(-3) = -(-3)^2 (1 - 0) = -9[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{x}(\mathrm{t}) \delta(\mathrm{t}+3) , \mathrm{dt} = x(-3) = -9[/latex]

question: Question 6 Consider a discrete-time linear time-invariant (LTI) system S , where [latex]\mathrm{y}[\mathrm{n}]={S}\{{x}[\mathrm{n}]\}[/latex] Let [latex]S\{\delta[n]\}= \begin{cases}1, & \mathrm{n} \in\{0,1,2\}\\  0, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases}[/latex] Where [latex]\delta[\mathrm{n}][/latex] is the discrete-time unit impulse function. For an input signal [latex]x[n][/latex], the output [latex]y[n][/latex] is
solution:
The impulse response of discrete-time LTI system is given as [latex]\mathrm{h}(\mathrm{n})=\delta(\mathrm{n})+\delta(\mathrm{n}-1)+\delta(\mathrm{n}-2)[/latex] For an input [latex]\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n})[/latex], the output [latex]\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{n})[/latex] is given by [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{y}(\mathrm{n}) & =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}) * \mathrm{~h}(\mathrm{n}) \\
& =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}) *[\delta(\mathrm{n})+\delta(\mathrm{n}-1)+\delta(\mathrm{n}-2)] \\
& =\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n})+\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}-1)+\mathrm{x}(\mathrm{n}-2)
\end{aligned}
[/latex]

question: Question 7 If the energy of a continuous-time signal [latex] x(t) [/latex] is [latex] E [/latex] and the energy of the signal [latex] 2 x(2 t-1) [/latex] is [latex] c E [/latex], then [latex] c [/latex] is ______ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
x(t) & \rightarrow E \text { (energy) } \\
x(t-1) & \rightarrow E \\
x(2 t-1) & \rightarrow \frac{E}{2} \\
2 x(2 t-1) & \rightarrow(2)^{2}(E / 2)=2 E=C E \\
C & =2
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

question:
Question 10 The input [latex] x(t) [/latex] and the output [latex] y(t) [/latex] of a system are related as [latex]
y(t)=e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t} e^{\tau} x(\tau) d \tau, \quad-\infty \lt t \lt \infty
 [/latex] The system is
solution:
System will follow law of superposition. Therefore, system will be linear. Time-invariance check: [latex]
y\left(t-t_{0}\right)=e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{\tau} \cdot x(\tau) d \tau
 [/latex] For input [latex] x\left(t-t_{0}\right) [/latex], output will be [latex]
y(t)=e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t} e^{\tau} \cdot x\left(\tau-t_{0}\right) d \tau
 [/latex] Put [latex] \tau-t_{o}=k [/latex], then [latex] d \tau=d k [/latex] and for [latex] \tau=t, k=t-t_{0} [/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
& =e^{-t} \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k+t_{0}} \cdot x(k) d k \\
& =e^{-t} \times e^{t o} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k} \cdot x(k) d k=e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{k} \cdot x(k) d k \\
& =e^{-\left(t-t_{0}\right)} \times \int_{-\infty}^{t-t_{0}} e^{\tau} \cdot x(\tau) d \tau
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] Since, [latex]
y(t)=y\left(t-t_{0}\right)
 [/latex] So, the system is time-invariant.

question: Question 11 Let [latex] X(\omega) [/latex] be the Fourier transform of the signal, [latex] x(t)=e^{-t^{4}} \cos t,-\infty \lt  t \lt \infty [/latex]. The value of the derivative of [latex] X(\omega) [/latex] at [latex] \omega=0 [/latex] at is _____ (rounded off to 1 decimal place)
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
t x(t) & \rightleftarrows j \frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega} \\
f(t) & =\frac{t x(t)}{j} \rightleftarrows \frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega}=F(\omega) \\
\left.\frac{d X(\omega)}{d \omega}\right|_{\omega=0} & =\left.F(\omega)\right|_{\omega=0}=\text { area of } f(t) \\
& =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{t x(t)}{j} d t=\text { area of odd-function } \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
 [/latex] [latex]
\left[\begin{array}{l}
\because x(t)=\text { even-function } \\
\therefore \frac{t}{j} x(t)=\text { odd-function }
\end{array}\right]
 [/latex]

[/latex] [latex]

 \omega_{1}&=\frac{15 \pi}{8} \\

question: Question 26 Let [latex]f(t)[/latex] be an even function, i.e. [latex]f(-t)=f(t)[/latex] for all t. Let the Fourier transform of [latex]f(t)[/latex] be defined as [latex]F\left ( \omega \right )=\int\limits_{-\infty }^{\infty }\:f\left ( t \right )e^{-j\omega t}dt[/latex]. Suppose [latex]\dfrac{dF\left ( \omega \right )}{d\omega }=-\omega F\left ( \omega \right )[/latex] for all [latex]\omega[/latex], and [latex]F(0)=1[/latex]. Then
solution: [latex]f(t) \rightleftharpoons F(\omega)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f(t) e^{-j \omega t} d t[/latex] The following informations are given about [latex]f(t) \rightleftharpoons F(\omega).[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} (i) f(t)=f(-t)\\ (ii) \left.F(\omega)\right|_{\omega=0}=1\\ (iii) \frac{d F(\omega)}{d \omega}=-\omega F(\omega)\\ \text{From }(iii), \frac{d F(\omega)}{d \omega}+\omega F(\omega)=0 \end{array}[/latex] By solving the above linear differential equations, (by mathematics) [latex] \begin{aligned} \ln F(\omega) &=-\frac{\omega^{2}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad F(\omega) &=K \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 2} \\ \text { Put } \omega=0, \qquad\qquad F(0) &=K \\ \Rightarrow \qquad\qquad 1 &=K \text { (from info. } \\ \text { From (iv), } \qquad\qquad F(\omega) &=e^{-\omega^{2} / 2} \\ \text{As we know}, e^{-a t^{2}}, a \gt 0 &\rightleftharpoons \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{a}} e^{-\omega^{2} / 4 a}\\ \text{At }a=\frac{1}{2}, \qquad\qquad\quad e^{-t^{2} / 2} &\rightleftharpoons \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{1 / 2}} \cdot e^{-\omega^{2} / 2}\\ f(t)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-t^{2} / 2} \rightleftharpoons e^{-\omega^{2} / 2}=F(\omega)\\ \text { Thus, }\qquad\qquad f(t)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} e^{-t^{2} / 2} \\ \text { At } t=0, \qquad\qquad f(0)&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \lt 1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 The casual signal with z-transformer [latex]Z^{2}\left ( Z-a \right )^{-2}[/latex] is ([latex]u[n][/latex] is the unit step signal)
solution: As we know, [latex] \begin{aligned} n \cdot a^{n} u(n) & \rightleftharpoons \frac{a z}{(z-a)^{2}} \\ \frac{1}{a} \cdot n \cdot a^{n} u(n) & \rightleftharpoons \frac{z}{(z-a)^{2}} \\ f(n) &=n \cdot a^{n-1} u(n) \rightleftharpoons \frac{z}{(z-a)^{2}}=F(z) \end{aligned}[/latex] Time-shifting property, [latex] \begin{aligned} f(n) &\rightleftharpoons F(z) \\ f(n+1) &\rightleftharpoons z \cdot F(z) & \\ x(n)&=(n+1) a^{n} u(n+1) \rightleftharpoons \frac{z^{2}}{(z-a)^{2}}=X(z) & \\ \text{Thus},\qquad \qquad x(n)&=(n+1) a^{n} u(n+1)=(n+1) a^{n} \cdot u(n) \\ &[\because(n+1) u(n+1)=(n+1) u(n) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Two discrete-time linear time-invariant systems with impulse responses [latex]h_{1}\left [ n \right ]=\delta \left [ n-1 \right ]+\delta \left [ n+1 \right ][/latex] and [latex]h_{2}\left [ n \right ]=\delta \left [ n\right ]+\delta \left [ n-1 \right ][/latex] are connected in cascade, where [latex]\delta \left [ n\right ][/latex] is the Kronecker delta. The impulse response of the cascaded system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n) &=\text { Resultant impulse response } \\ &=h_{1}(n) * h_{2}(n) \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying z -transform [latex] \begin{aligned} H(z) &=H_{1}(z) \cdot H_{2}(z) \\ &=\left(z+z^{-1}\right)\left(1+z^{-1}\right) \\ &=z+Z^{-1}+1+z^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] By applying inverse ZT, [latex] h(n)=\delta(n+1)+\delta(n-1)+\delta(n)+\delta(n-2)[/latex]

question: Question 29 If the input x(t) and output y(t) of a system are related as [latex]y\left ( t \right )=\text{max}\left ( 0,x\left ( t \right ) \right )[/latex], then the system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t) &=\max (0, x(t)) \\ &=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} 0, & x(t) \lt 0 \\ x(t), & x(t)\gt 0 \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}[/latex] Linearity check: at input [latex]x_{1}(t)=-2[/latex], output [latex]y_{1}(t)=0 [/latex] at input [latex]x_{2}(t)=1[/latex], output [latex]y_{2}(t)=1 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] system is non-linear because it violates law of additivity. Check for time-invariance : Delayed [latex]\mathrm{O} / \mathrm{P}:[/latex] [latex] y\left(t-t_{0}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} x\left(t-t_{0}\right), & x\left(t-t_{0}\right) \gt  0 \\ 0 & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\lt 0 \end{array}\right.[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{O} / \mathrm{P}[/latex] of system when input is [latex]x\left(t-t_{0}\right)=f(t)[/latex] [latex] y_{1}(t)=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} f(t), & f(t) \gt 0 \\ 0, & f(t)\lt 0 \end{array}=\left\{\begin{array}{cl} x\left(t-t_{0}\right), & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\gt  0 \\ 0, & x\left(t-t_{0}\right)\lt 0 \end{array}\right.\right.[/latex] Therefore, system is time-invariant.

Question 34 Which of the following statements is true about the two sided Laplace transform?
solution: It has no poles for any bounded signal that is nonzero in a finite time interval. This is true as we know for finite amplitude finite width signal ROC is entire s plane and ROC never includes any pole. It implies for such signals there is no poles. Hence the correct answer is option (B).

options.A: It exists for every signal that may or may not have a Fourier transform.

options.D:
If a signal can be expressed as a weighted sum of shifted one sided exponentials,

question: Question 35 A periodic function [latex]f(t)[/latex], with a period of [latex]2\pi[/latex], is represented as its Fourier series, [latex]f(t)=a_0+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }a_n\cos nt+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }a_n\sin nt[/latex]. If [latex]f(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} A \sin t, & 0\leq t\leq \pi\\ 0,& \pi\lt t\lt 2\pi \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] the Fourier series coefficients [latex]a_1 \; and \; b_1[/latex] of [latex]f(t)[/latex] are
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
T_0 &=2\pi \Rightarrow \;\omega _0=\frac{2\pi}{T_0}=1 \\ 
\text{Now, }b_1 &=\frac{2}{T_0}\int_{0}^{T_0}f(t) \sin \omega _0 t \; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{2}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}f(t) \sin t \; dt\;\;[\because \omega _0=1]\\ 
 &= \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi} A \sin t \cdot \sin t\; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{A}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{\pi}2 \sin ^2 t \; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{A}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{\pi}[1-\cos 2t] \; dt \\ 
 &=\frac{A}{2 \pi} \left [ t-\frac{\sin 2t}{2} \right ]_0^{\pi} \\ 
 &= \frac{A}{2 \pi} [(\pi-0)-(0-0)]=\frac{A}{2}\\ 
 a_1&=\frac{2}{T_0}\int_{0}^{T_0}f(t) \cos \omega _0 t \; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{2}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}f(t) \cos t \; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi} A \sin t \cdot \cos t\; dt \\ 
 &= \frac{A}{2 \pi}\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin 2t \; dt=0
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 The output response of a system is denoted as y(t), and its Laplace transform is given by [latex]Y(s)=\frac{10}{s(s^2+s+100\sqrt{2})}[/latex] The steady state value of y(t) is
solution: Steady state value of y(t) [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\lim_{s \to 0}sY(s)\\ &=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{10s}{s(s^2+s+100\sqrt{2})}\\ &=\frac{10}{100\sqrt{2}}=\frac{1}{10\sqrt{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 A system transfer function is [latex]H(s)=\frac{a_1s^2+b_1s+c_1}{a_2s^2+b_2s+c_2}[/latex]. If [latex]a_1=b_1=0[/latex], and  all other coefficients are positive, the transfer function represents a
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s)&=\frac{c_1}{a_2s^2+b_2s+c_2}\\ & as \;\; a_1=b_1=0\\ &=\frac{c_1}{(1+s\tau _1)(1+s\tau _2)}\\ \text{Put }s&=0,\; H(0)=\frac{c_1}{c_2}\\ \text{Put }s&=\infty ,\; H(\infty )=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] which represents second order low pass filter.

question: Question 39 The inverse Laplace transform of [latex]H(s)=\frac{s+3}{s^2+2s+1} \; for \; t\geq 0[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L^{-1}\left ( \frac{s+3}{s^2+2s+1} \right )&=L^{-1}\left ( \frac{s+1+2}{(s+1)^2} \right )\\ &=L^{-1}\left ( \frac{1}{s+1}+\frac{2}{(s+1)^2} \right )\\ &=e^{-t}+2te^{-t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The Fourier transform of a continuous-time signal x(t) is given by [latex]X(\omega )=\frac{1}{(10+j\omega )^{2}},-\infty \lt \omega \lt  \infty[/latex], where  [latex] j=\sqrt{-1} \; and \; \omega[/latex] denotes frequency. Then the value of |lnx(t)| at t=1 is ___________ (up to 1 decimal place). ( ln denotes the logarithm to base e )
solution: [latex]x(t)\rightleftharpoons X(j\omega )=\frac{1}{(10+j\omega )^2}[/latex] By taking inverse Fourier transform, [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=te^{-10t}u(t) \\ \text{Now, } x(t)_{t=1}&= 1 \times e^{-10} \times 1=e^{-10}\\ \text{Thus, }|\ln (x(t))| &= |\ln (e^{-10})|=|-10|=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 A cascade system having the impulse responses [latex]h_1(n)=\{\overset{1}{\uparrow},-1\}[/latex] and [latex]h_2(n)=\{\overset{1}{\uparrow},1\}[/latex] is shown in the
figure below, where symbol [latex]\uparrow[/latex]
 denotes the time origin. The input sequence x(n) for which the cascade system produces an output sequence
[latex]y(n)=\{\overset{1}{\uparrow},2,1,-1,-2,-1\}[/latex] is
solution: Now, [latex]\begin{aligned} h(n)&=\text{overall system impulse response}\\ &=h_1(n)*h_2(n)\\ &=\{1,-1\}*\{1,1\}\\ &=\{ 1,0,-1\}\underset{*}{\rightleftharpoons }H(z)=1-z^2\\ &\text{As we know,}\\ H(z)&=\frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}\Rightarrow X(z)=\frac{Y(z)}{H(z)}\\ &=\frac{1+2z^{-1}+z^{-2}-z^{-3}-2z^{-4}-z^{-5}}{1-z^{-2}}\\ &=1+2z^{-1}+2z^{-2}+z^{-3}\\ \Rightarrow \; x(n)&=\{1,2,2,1\} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 The output y(t) of the following system is to be sampled, so as to reconstruct it from its samples
uniquely. The required minimum sampling rate is
solution: From the above block diagram, [latex]Z(t)=x(t) \cos 1000 \pi t[/latex] By using modulation property of fourier transform, [latex]Z(\omega )=\frac{1}{2}[X(\omega + 1000 \pi t)+X(\omega - 1000 \pi t)][/latex] Now, [latex]h(t)=\frac{\sin 1500 \pi t}{\pi t}=1500 Sa(1500 \pi t)[/latex] Thus, [latex]H(\omega )[/latex] is a low pass filter and it will pass frequency, component of [latex]Z(\omega )[/latex] upto [latex]1500 \pi [/latex] rad/sec. Therefore, maximum frequency component of [latex]y(t)[/latex] is [latex]\omega _m =1500 \pi[/latex] rad/sec  or [latex]f_m =750 Hz[/latex] So, the minimum sampling rate for [latex]y(t)[/latex] is [latex]f_{s\; min}=2f_m=1500Hz=1500[/latex] samples/sec

question: Question 48 Let the signal [latex]x(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{+\infty }(-1)^{k}\delta (t-\frac{k}{2000})[/latex] be passed through an LTI system with frequency response [latex]H(\omega)[/latex] , as given in the figure below The Fourier series representation of the output is given as
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty } (-1)^K \delta \left ( t-\frac{K}{2000} \right )\\ &= \sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty } (-1)^K \delta (t-KT)\\ \text{where, } &=T=\frac{1}{2000} \end{aligned}[/latex] Time period: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_0&=2T=\frac{1}{1000}\\ \omega _0&=\frac{2\pi}{T_0}=2000 \pi \; rad \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, x(t) is even-halt wave symmetric. So, its expansion will contain only odd harmonics of cos. Therefore, coefficient of fundamental harmonic is [latex]\begin{aligned} a_1&=\frac{2}{T}\int_{-T_0/2}^{T_0/2}x(t) \cos \omega _0 t \; dt\\ &=\frac{4}{T_0}\int_{0}^{T_0/2}\delta (t) \cos \omega _0 t \; dt\\ &=\frac{4}{T_0}\int_{0}^{T_0/2}\delta (t) \cos 0 \; dt\\ &=\frac{4}{T_0}\left [\int_{0}^{T_0/2}\delta (t) \; dt \right ]\\ &=\frac{4}{T_0}=4000 \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, frequency components available in expansion are [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega _0,3\omega _0,...\\ 2000\pi, 6000 \pi,... \end{aligned}[/latex] As, LTI system given in the question will pass upto [latex]5000\pi[/latex] rad/sec frequency component of input.So, output will have only one component of sfrequency [latex]2000\pi[/latex] rad/sec Thus, y(t)= expansion of output [latex]=a_1 \cos \omega _0 t=4000 \cos 2000 \pi t[/latex]

question:
Question 49 Consider a causal and stable LTI system with rational transfer function H(z). Whose
corresponding impulse response begins at n = 0. Furthermore, [latex]H(1)=\frac{5}{4}[/latex]. The poles of H(z) are [latex]P_{k}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}exp(j\frac{(2k-1)\pi }{4})[/latex] for k = 1,2,3,4. The zeros of H(z) are all at z = 0. Let [latex]g[n]=j^nh[n][/latex]. The value of g[8] equals ___________.
solution:
Pole locationof H(z) are given as, [latex]\begin{aligned} z&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}e^{j(2K-1)\frac{\pi}{4}};\;\;K=1,2,3,4\\ z_1&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}e^{j\frac{\pi}{4}} =\frac{1}{2}(1+j)\\ z_2&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}e^{j\frac{3\pi}{4}} =\frac{1}{2}(-1+j)\\ z_3&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}e^{j\frac{5\pi}{4}} =\frac{1}{2}(-1-j)\\ z_4&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}e^{j\frac{7\pi}{4}} =\frac{1}{2}(1-j)\\ \text{Now,}\\ H(z)&=\frac{K\cdot z^4}{(z-z_1)(z-z_2)(z-z_3)(z-z_4)}...(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] [As h(n) is causal and it starts from n=0, so numerator will have same order as denominator is having]. by solving equation (i) [latex]\begin{aligned}
H(z)&=\frac{K\cdot z^4}{z^4+\frac{1}{4}}\;\;...(ii)\\
&\text{Given that,}\\
H(1)&=\frac{5}{4}\\
&\text{From equation (ii),}\\
H(1)&=\frac{K}{1+\frac{1}{4}}\Rightarrow \frac{5}{4}=\frac{K}{\frac{5}{4}}\\
\Rightarrow \; K&=\frac{25}{16}\\
H(z)&=\frac{\frac{25}{16}z^4}{z^4+\frac{1}{4}}\\
&\text{By using division rule,}\\
H(z)&=\frac{25}{16}\left [ 1+\frac{1}{4}z^{-4}+\frac{1}{16}z^{-8}+... \right ]\\
\text{Thus, }h(8)&=\frac{1}{16} \times \frac{25}{16}=0.097\\
&\text{it is given that,}\\
g(n)&=j^nh(n)\\
g(8)&=j^8h(8)=h(8)\\
\Rightarrow \; g(8)&=h(8)=0.097
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 Consider the system with following input-output relation y[n]=[latex](1+(-1)^{n})x[n][/latex] where, x[n] is the input and y[n] is the output. The system is

question:
Question 51 Let z(t)=x(t) * y(t) , where "*" denotes convolution. Let c be a positive real-valued
constant. Choose the correct expression for z(ct).
solution: Time scaling property of convolution. If, [latex]x(t)*y(t)=z(t)[/latex] Then, [latex]x(ct)*y(ct)=\frac{1}{c} z(ct)[/latex] [latex]z(ct)=c \times x(ct) * y(ct)[/latex]

question: Question 52 Consider [latex]g(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} t-\left \lceil t \right \rceil, & t\geq 0 \\ t-\left \lceil t \right \rceil , & otherwise \end{matrix}\right. , \; \; where\; t \in \mathbb{R}[/latex] Here, [latex]\left \lfloor t \right \rfloor[/latex] represents the largest integer less than or equal to t and [latex]\left \lceil t \right \rceil [/latex] denotes the smallest integer greater than or equal to t. The coefficient of the second harmonic component of the Fourier series representing g(t) is _________.
solution: Given that, [latex]g(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} t-\left \lfloor t \right \rfloor, & t \geq 0\\ t-\left \lceil t \right \rceil & \text{otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] where, [latex]\left \lfloor t \right \rfloor=[/latex] greatest integer less than or equal to 't'. [latex]\left \lceil t \right \rceil=[/latex] smallest integer greater than or equal to 't'. Now, Since,  g(t) is nonperiodic. So, there is no Fourier series expansion of this signal and hence no need to calculate harmonic here.

question: Question 53 The value of the integral [latex]2\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }(\frac{sin 2\pi t}{\pi t})dt[/latex] is equal to
solution: The Fourier transform of [latex]\begin{aligned} &\frac{2 \sin (t\tau /2)}{t}\rightarrow 2 \pi \text{rect}\left ( \frac{\omega }{\tau } \right ) \\ &\frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t}\rightarrow \text{rect} \left ( \frac{\omega }{4 \pi} \right )\\ &\text{So, }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} e^{-j\omega t}dt=\text{rect}\left ( \frac{\omega }{4 \pi} \right )\\ &\text{Putting }\omega =0 \text{ in the above equation} \\ & \int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} dt=1\\ &2\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \frac{\sin (2 \pi t)}{\pi t} dt=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 Let [latex]x_{1}(t)\leftrightarrow X_{1}(\omega ) \; and \; x_{2}(t) \leftrightarrow X_{2}(\omega \omega )[/latex] be two signals whose Fourier Transforms are as shown in the figure below. In the figure, [latex]h(t)=e^{-2|t|}[/latex] denotes the impulse response. For the system shown above, the minimum sampling rate required to sample y(t), so that y(t) can be uniquely reconstructed from its samples, is
solution: Given that, Bandwidth of [latex]X_1(\omega )=B_1[/latex] Bandwidth of [latex]X_2(\omega )=B_2[/latex] system has [latex]h(t)=e^{-2|t|}[/latex] and input to the system is [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] The bandwidth of [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] is [latex]B_1+B_2[/latex]. The bandwidth of output will be [latex]B_1+B_2[/latex]. So, sampling rate will be [latex]2(B_1+B_2)[/latex].

question: Question 55 Consider a linear time-invariant system with transfer function [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)}[/latex] If the input is cos(t) and the steady state output is [latex]A \cos (t+\alpha )[/latex], then the value of A is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(s)&=\frac{1}{(s+1)}\\ \text{Put, }s&=j\omega \\ H(j\omega)&=\frac{1}{j\omega+1}\\ |H(j\omega)|&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\omega ^2 +1}}\\ \because \; \text{ input }x(t)&=\cos (t)\\ \text{Here, } \omega &=1 \text{rad/sec}\\ \text{and }|x(t)|&=1\\ \text{hence, }&\text{steady state output}\\ y(t)&=|H(j\omega)|_{\omega=1} \cos (t+\angle H(j\omega)|_{\omega =1})\\ A&=|H(j\omega)|_{\omega =1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=0.707 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Let f(x) be a real, periodic function satisfying f(-x)=-f(x). The general form of its Fourier series representation would be
solution: Given that, [latex]f(-x)=-f(x)[/latex] So, function is an odd function. So, the fourier series will have sine term only. So, [latex]f(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty }b_x \sin (kx)[/latex]

question: Question 57 Suppose the maximum frequency in a band-limited signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is 5 kHz. Then, the maximum frequency in [latex]x(t)\cos (2000\pi t)[/latex], in kHz, is ________.
solution: Maximum possible frequency of [latex]x(t)(2000 \pi t)=f_1+f_2=5+1=6kHz[/latex]

question: Question 58 Consider a causal LTI system characterized by differential equation [latex]\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+\frac{1}{6}y(t)=3x(t)[/latex]. The response of the system to the input [latex]x(t)=3e^{-\frac{t}{3}}u(t)[/latex]. where u(t) denotes the unit step function, is
solution: The differential equation [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dy(t)}{dt} &+\frac{1}{6}y(t)=3x(t) \\ \text{So, }sY(s)&+\frac{1}{6}Y(s) =3X(s) \\ Y(s) &=\frac{3X(s)}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} \\ X(s) &=\frac{9}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )} \\ \text{So, } Y(s)&=\frac{9}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} \\ &=\frac{54}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{6} \right )} -\frac{54}{\left ( s+\frac{1}{3} \right )}\\ \text{So, }y(t) &= (54e^{-1/6t}-54e^{-1/3t})u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 59 The output of a continuous-time, linear time-invariant system is denoted by T{x(t)} where x(t) is the input signal. A signal z(t) is called eigen-signal of the system T, when [latex]T\{z(t)\} =  \gamma z(t)[/latex],
where [latex]\gamma[/latex] is a complex number, in general, and is called an eigenvalue of T. Suppose the impulse response of the system T is real and even. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: Given that impulse response is real and even, Thus [latex]H(j\omega )[/latex] will also be real and even. Since, [latex]H(j\omega )[/latex] is real and even thus, [latex]H(j\omega )=H(-j\omega )[/latex] Now, [latex]\cos (t)[/latex] is input i.e. [latex]\frac{e^{jt}+e^{-jt}}{2}[/latex] is input Output will be [latex]\frac{H(j1)e^{jt}+H(-j1)e^{-jt}}{2}=H(j1)\left ( \frac{e^{jt}+e^{-jt}}{2} \right )= H(j1) \cos (t)[/latex] If, [latex]\sin (t)[/latex] is input i.e. [latex]\frac{e^{jt}+e^{-jt}}{2}[/latex] is input Output will be [latex]\frac{H(j1)e^{jt}+H(-j1)e^{-jt}}{2}=H(j1)\left ( \frac{e^{jt}-e^{-jt}}{2j} \right )= H(j1) \sin (t)[/latex] So, [latex]\sin (t)[/latex] and [latex]\cos (t)[/latex] are eigen signal with same eigen values.

options.A: cos(t) is an eigen-signal but sin(t) is not
options.B: cos(t) and sin(t) are both eigen-signals but with different eigenvalues
options.C: sin(t) is an eigen-signal but cos(t) is not
options.D: cos(t) and sin(t) are both eigen-signals with identical eigenvalues

question: Question 60 Suppose [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \;  x_{2}(t)[/latex] have the Fourier transforms as shown below. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution: By observing [latex]X_1(j \omega )[/latex] and [latex]X_2(j \omega )[/latex], we can say that they are not conjugate symmetric. Since, the fourier transform is not conjugate symmetric the signal will not be real. So, [latex]x_1(t), x_2(t)[/latex] are not real. Now the fourier transform of [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] will be [latex]\frac{1}{2\pi}X_1(j \omega )*X_2(j \omega )[/latex] and by looking at [latex]X_1(j \omega )[/latex] and [latex]X_2(j \omega )[/latex], we can say that [latex]X_1(j \omega ) *X_2(j \omega )[/latex] will be conjugate symmetric and thus [latex]x_1(t) \cdot x_2(t)[/latex] will be real. By observing [latex]X_1(j \omega )[/latex] and [latex]X_2(j \omega )[/latex], we can say, [latex]X_2( \omega )=X_1(- \omega )\overset{IFT}{\rightarrow}x_2(t)=x_1(-t)\;\;...(i)[/latex] Now, [latex]X_1(j \omega )[/latex] is real. Therefore, [latex]x_1(t)[/latex] will be conjugate symmetric. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{i.e., } x_1(t)&=x_1^*(-t) \\ \downarrow t&= -t\\ x_1(-t)&= x_1^*(t)\\ \text{Now, }x_1(t)\cdot x_2(t) &= x_1(t)\cdot x_1(-t) \;\;(from \;(i))\\ &= x_1(t)\cdot x_1^*(t)\\ &= |x_1(t)|^2=\text{real function} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \; x_{2}(t)[/latex] are complex and [latex]x_{1}(t) x_{2}(t)[/latex] is also complex with nonzero imaginary part
options.B: [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \; x_{2}(t)[/latex] are real and [latex]x_{1}(t) x_{2}(t)[/latex] is also real
options.C: [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \; x_{2}(t)[/latex] are complex but [latex]x_{1}(t) x_{2}(t)[/latex] is real
options.D: [latex]x_{1}(t) \; and \; x_{2}(t)[/latex] are imaginary but [latex]x_{1}(t) x_{2}(t)[/latex] is real

question: Question 61 Consider the following state-space representation of a linear time-invariant system. [latex]\dot{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0&2 \end{bmatrix}x(t), [/latex]  [latex]y(t)=c^{T}x(t),  [/latex]  [latex]c=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} [/latex]   and [latex]x(0)=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The value of y(t) for [latex]t= log_{e}2[/latex]  is______.

Question 62 Let [latex]S=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n\alpha ^{n} \; where \;  |\alpha | \lt 1[/latex]. The value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] in the range [latex]0 \lt \alpha \lt 1[/latex], such that [latex]S= 2\alpha[/latex]  is _______.
solution: The Z-transform of [latex]\begin{aligned} \alpha ^n u(n)&\rightarrow \frac{1}{(1-\alpha Z^{-1})}\\ n\alpha ^n u(n)&\rightarrow \frac{\alpha Z^{-1}}{(1-\alpha Z^{-1})^2}\\ \frac{\alpha Z^{-1}}{(1-\alpha Z^{-1})^2}&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n\alpha ^nZ^{-n} \end{aligned}[/latex] If we put Z=1 in above equation, we get, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{\alpha }{(1-\alpha )^2}&=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n\alpha ^n\\ \text{Since, }\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n\alpha ^n&=2\alpha =\frac{\alpha }{(1-\alpha )^2}\\ \text{So,}2&=\frac{1}{(1-\alpha )^2}\\ \Rightarrow \;\;\alpha &=0.29 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 63 The value of [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{+\infty }e^{-t}\delta (2t-2)dt, \; where \; \delta (t)[/latex] is the Dirac delta function, is
solution: To find the value of [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }e^{-t}\delta (2t-2)dt[/latex] Since, [latex]\delta (2t-2)=\frac{1}{2}\delta (1t-1)[/latex]  above integral can be written as [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }e^{-t}\frac{1}{2}\delta (t-1)dt=\frac{1}{2}e^{-1}=\frac{1}{2e}[/latex]

question: Question 64 Consider a continuous-time system with input x(t) and output y(t) given by y(t) = x(t) cos(t) This system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=x(t)\cos (t)\\ &\text{To check linearity,}\\ y_1(t)&=x_1(t)\cos (t)\\ &[y_1(t) \text{ is output for }x_1(t)]\\ y_2(t)&=x_2(t) \cos (t)\\ &[y_2(t) \text{ is output for }x_2(t)]\\ \text{so, the}& \text{ output for }(x_1(t)+ x_2(t)) \text{ will be}\\ y(t)&=[x_1(t)+ x_2(t)]\cos (t)\\ &=y_1(t)+y_2(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the system is linear, to check time invariance. The delayed output, [latex]y(t-t_0)=x(t-t_0)\cos (t-t_0)[/latex] The output for delayed input, [latex]y(t, t_0)=x(t-t_0)\cos (t)[/latex] Since,  [latex]y(t-t_0)\neq y(t,t_0)[/latex] System is time varying.

question: Question 65 The transfer function of a system is [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{s}{s+2}[/latex]. The steady state output y(t) is [latex] A \cos (2t+\varphi)[/latex] for the input cos(2t). The values of A and [latex]\varphi[/latex], respectively are
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
 \frac{Y(s)}{R(s)}&=\frac{s}{s+2} \\ 
 y(t)&=A \cos (2t+\phi ),  \\ 
 r(t)&=\cos 2t \\ 
\because \;H(s) &=\frac{s}{(s+2)} \\ 
 H(j\omega )&=\frac{j\omega }{j\omega +2} \\ 
|H(j\omega )| &=\frac{\omega }{\sqrt{\omega ^2+4 }} \\ 
\angle H(j\omega ) &=90^{\circ} -\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{\omega }{2} \right ) \\ 
\because \; \omega &= 2 \text{  (as given)}\\ 
|H(j\omega )| &=\frac{2}{\sqrt{4+4}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ 
|H(j\omega )| &=90^{\circ} -\tan ^{-1}(1)=45^{\circ} \\ 
\because \; \text{hence, }A &=1 \times |H(j\omega )|_{\omega =2}\\
&=1 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=0.707\\
\phi &= 45^{\circ}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 The z-Transform of a sequence x[n] is given as [latex]X(z)=2z+4-4/z+3/z^{2}[/latex]. If y[n] is the first difference of x[n], then Y(z) is given by
solution: [latex]y(n)[/latex] is first difference of [latex]x(n)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{so, } y(n)&=x(n)-x(n-1) \\ \text{so, } Y(z)&=X(z)-z^{-1}X(z) \\ Y(z)&=(2z+4-4z^{-1}+3z^{-2})\\ &-(2+4z^{-1}-4z^{-2}+3z^{-3}) \\ Y(z) &=2z+2-8z^{-1}+7z^{-2}-3z^{-3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 70 Consider a signal defined by [latex]x(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^{j10t} & for |t|\leq 1\\ 0 & for |t|\gt 1 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Its Fourier Transform is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Since, }x(t) &=\left\{\begin{matrix} e^{j10t} &\text{for }|t|\leq 1 \\ 0& \text{for }|t|\gt 1 \end{matrix}\right. \\ \text{as, } X(\omega )&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty } x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt\\ \text{so, } X(\omega )&=\int_{-1}^{1 } e^{j10t}e^{-j\omega t}dt\\ &=\int_{-1}^{1 } e^{jt(10-\omega )}dt\\ &= \frac{1}{j(10-\omega )}[e^{j(10-\omega )}- e^{-j(10-\omega )}]\\ X(\omega ) &=\frac{2 \sin (\omega -10)}{(\omega -10)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 The Laplace transform of [latex]f(t)=2\sqrt{t/\pi } [/latex] is [latex] s^{-3/2}[/latex]. The Laplace transform of [latex]g(t)=\sqrt{1/\pi t}[/latex] is
solution: Given that, [latex]f(t)=2\sqrt{\frac{t}{\pi}}\rightleftharpoons F(s)=s^{-3/2}[/latex] By using property of differentiation In time, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{df(t)}{dt}&\rightleftharpoons sF(s) \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\cdot \frac{1}{2}t^{-1/2}&\rightleftharpoons sF(s) \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi t}}&\rightleftharpoons s\cdot s^{-3/2} \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi t}}&\rightleftharpoons s^{-1/2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 Consider a discrete time signal given by [latex]x[n]=(-0.25)^{n}u[n]+(0.5)^{n}u[-n-1][/latex] The region of convergence of its Z-transform would be

The right sided signal will have pole at location with magnitude 0.25. So, ROC is [latex]|z| \gt 0.25[/latex]. The left sided signal will have pole at location with magnitude 0.5. So, ROC is [latex]|z| \lt 0.5[/latex]. So, ROC of X(z) (Z-transform of x(n) will be ) [latex]0.25 \lt |z| \lt 0.5[/latex].

options.A: the region inside the circle of radius 0.5 and centered at origin

question: Question 75 A moving average function is given by [latex]y(t)=\frac{1}{T}\int_{t-T}^{t}u(\tau )d\tau[/latex]. If the input u is a sinusoidal signal of frequency [latex]\frac{1}{2\tau }[/latex] Hz, then in steady state, the output y will lag u (in degree) by ______ .
solution:
System input: [latex]\sin \omega _0 t[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
f_0&=\frac{1}{2T}Hz\\
\text{Therefore,}\\
\omega _0&=2 \pi f_0=\frac{2 \pi}{2T}=\frac{\pi}{T}\; rad/sec\\
y(t)&=\frac{1}{T}\int_{t-T}^{t}\sin \omega _0\tau \; d\tau\\
&=\frac{1}{T}[-\cos\omega _0 t ]_{t-T}^t\\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t -\cos\omega _0 (t-T) ]\\
&\left [ \because \; \omega _0=\frac{t}{T} \right ]\\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t -\cos\left ( \frac{\pi t}{T}- \pi \right ) ]\\ \\
&=-\frac{1}{T}[\cos\omega _0 t +\cos\omega _0 t ]\\
&=-\frac{2}{T} \cos\omega _0 t \\
&=\frac{2}{T}\sin (\omega _0 t -90^{\circ}) \\
&=\text{Output is lagging by }90^{\circ} \text{ w.r.t. input.}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 A signal is represented by [latex]x(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 &|t| \lt 1 \\ 0& |t|\gt 1 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The Fourier transform of the convolved signal [latex]y(t)= x(2t)* x(t/2)[/latex] is
solution: Given signal can be drawn as Therefore, [latex]\begin{aligned} &x(t)\leftrightarrow X(\omega )=2Sa(\omega ) \\ &\text{Now, } x(t)\leftrightarrow X(\omega )\\ &\text{then by time scaling,} \\ &x(at)\leftrightarrow \frac{1}{|a|}X(\omega /a) \\ &\therefore \; x(2t)\leftrightarrow Sa \left ( \frac{\omega }{2} \right )\;\;...(i) \\ &x\left ( \frac{t}{2} \right ) \leftrightarrow 4Sa(2\omega )\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{Now, }y(t)=x(2t) \times x(t/2) \end{aligned}[/latex] Convolution in time domain multiplication in frequency domain [latex]\begin{aligned} Y(\omega )&=4Sa\left ( \frac{\omega }{2}\right ) Sa(2\omega ) \\ Y(\omega )&=\frac{4\sin \left ( \frac{\omega }{2}\right ) }{\left ( \frac{\omega }{2}\right ) } \frac{\sin (2\omega )}{2\omega }\\ Y(\omega )&=\frac{4}{\omega ^2}\sin \left ( \frac{\omega }{2}\right ) \sin (2\omega ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 82 An input signal x(t)=2+5sin(100[latex]\pi[/latex]t) is sampled with a sampling frequency of
400 Hz and applied to the system whose transfer function is represented by [latex]\frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}=\frac{1}{N}(\frac{1-z^{-N}}{1-z^{-1}})[/latex] where, N represents the number of samples per cycle. The output y(n) of the system under steady state is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_s&= 400Hz\\ x(t)&=2+5 \sin (100 \pi t) \\ t\rightarrow xT_s &=\frac{n}{f_s}=\frac{n}{400} \\ x(n)&=2+5 \sin \left ( 100 \pi\frac{n}{400} \right ) \\ &= 2+5 \sin \frac{\pi}{4}n\\ \text{Here, }\omega _0 &=\frac{\pi}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, N= time-period of [latex]x(n)=\frac{2 \pi }{\omega _0}=\frac{2 \pi}{\pi/4}=0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Now, }H(z)&=\frac{1}{N}\left [ \frac{1-z^{-N}}{1-z^{-1}} \right ] \\ \text{Applying, }z &=e^{j\omega } \\ H(e^{j\omega }) &= \frac{1}{N}\left [ \frac{1-e^{-j\omega N}}{1-e^{-j\omega }} \right ] \\ \text{For, } &\text{sinusoidal part of }x(n): \\ H(e^{j\omega _0 }) &= \frac{1}{N}\left [ \frac{1-e^{-j\omega _0 N}}{1-e^{-j\omega _0 }} \right ] \\ [\text{Note: }] \omega _0 N&=\frac{\pi}{4} \times 8 =2 \pi] \\ &= \frac{1}{N}\left [ \frac{1-e^{-j2 \pi N}}{1-e^{-j \pi/4}} \right ]=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, for sinusoidal part of input, system output is zero. For dc part of input, [latex]\begin{aligned} y(n)&=\text{output}\\ &=H(e^{j0}) \times \text{input dc value}\\ [\because \; &H(e^{j\omega })_{\omega =0}=1]\\ &=1 \times 2=2 \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, steady state output = 2

question:
Question 83 A discrete system is represented by the difference equation [latex]\begin{bmatrix} X_{1}(k+1)\\ X_{2}(k+1) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} a & a-1\\ a+1& a \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} X_{1}(k)\\ X_{2}(k) \end{bmatrix}[/latex] It has initial conditions [latex]X_1(0)=1;X_2(0)=0[/latex]. The pole locations of the system
for a = 1, are
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{bmatrix} X_1(K+1)\\X_2(K+1) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} a & a-1\\ a+1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} X_1(K)\\X_2(K) \end{bmatrix}[/latex] With initial conditions, [latex]X_1(0)=1,\;\;X_2(0)=0[/latex] For a=1, we can write, [latex]\begin{bmatrix} X_1(K+1)\\X_2(K+1) \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} X_1(K)\\X_2(K+) \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; X_1(K+1)=X_1(K) \;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; X_2(K+1)=2X_1(K)+X_2(k) \;\;...(ii)[/latex] Applying z-transform on equation (i), [latex]\begin{aligned} zX_1(z)-zX_1(0)&=X_1(z) \\ X_1(z)[z-1]&=zX_1(0) \\ X_1(z) =\frac{z}{z-1}\;\;&[Given, \; X_1(0)=1]...(iii) \\ \text{from equation (ii),}\\ zX_2(z)-zX_2(0)&=2X_1(z)+X_2(z)\\ X_2(z)[z-1]&=2X_1(z)+zX_2(0)\\ [Given,\;\; X_2(0)&=0]\\ \frac{X_2(z)}{X_1(z)}&=\frac{2}{z-1} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thus, transfer function, [latex]H(z)=\frac{2}{z-1}[/latex] Therefore, pole location is z=1.

question: Question 84 Consider an LTI system with impulse response [latex]h(t)=e^{-5t}u(t)[/latex]. If the output of the system is [latex]y(t)=e^{-3t}u(t)-e^{-5t}u(t)[/latex] then the input, x(t), is given by
solution: Impulse response of an LTI system = transfer function [latex]=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=H(s)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{where, } y(t)&=e^{-3t}u(t)-e^{-5t}u(t) \\ \therefore \; Y(s) &=\frac{1}{(s+3)}-\frac{1}{(s+5)} \\ &=\frac{2}{(s+3)(s+5)} \\ \text{Also, } h(t)&=e^{-5t}u(t) \\ \therefore \; H(s) &=\frac{1}{(s+5)} \\ \text{Therefore, } X(s)&=\frac{Y(s)}{H(s)} \\ &=\frac{2}{(s+3)(s+5)} \times (s+5) \\ &= \frac{2}{(s+3)}\\ \therefore \; \text{Input}&=x(t)=2e^{-3t}u(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Consider an LTI system with transfer function [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+4)}[/latex] If the input to the system is cos(3t) and the steady state output is Asin(3t+[latex]\alpha[/latex]) , then the value of A is
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned}
H(s)&=\frac{1}{s(s+4)}\\
r(t)&=\text{input}= \cos (3t)=\cos \omega t\\
\therefore \; \omega &=3 \text{ rad/s}\\
H(j\omega)&=\frac{1}{(j\omega)(j\omega+4)}\\
\text{Now, }|H(j\omega)|&=\frac{1}{\omega \sqrt{\omega^4+4^2}}\\
&=\frac{1}{3\sqrt{25}}=\frac{1}{15} \;\;\;(at\; \omega=3)\\
\angle H(j\omega)&=-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1}\frac{\omega}{4}\\
&=-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1}\frac{3}{4}=-126.86^{\circ}\\
\therefore \; c(t)&=\frac{1}{15} \cos (3t-126.86^{\circ})\\
&=\frac{1}{15} \sin (3t-36.86^{\circ})\;\;...(i)\\
c(t)&=A \sin (3t+\alpha )\;\;...(ii)\\
\text{Comparing }&\text{ eq. (i) and (ii), we have,}\\
A&=\frac{1}{15}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 Let f(t) be a continuous time signal and let F([latex]\omega[/latex]) be its Fourier Transform defined by [latex]F(\omega)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }f(t)e^{-j \omega t}dt[/latex] Define g(t) by [latex]g(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-jut}du[/latex] What is the relationship between f(t) and g(t) ?
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned} f(t)&\rightleftharpoons F(\omega )\\ g(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-jut}du\\ \text{Now, }f(t)&=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(\omega)e^{j \omega t}d\omega \\ \Rightarrow \; 2 \pi f(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(\omega)e^{j \omega t}d\omega \\ \omega &\rightarrow u,\\ 2 \pi f(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{j u t}du \\ t &\rightarrow -t,\\ 2 \pi f(-t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }F(u)e^{-j u t}du \\ &=g(t)\\ \Rightarrow \; g(t)&=2 \pi f(-t)\\ &= 2\pi f(t) \end{aligned}[/latex] [If [latex]f(t)[/latex] is even then [latex]f(t)=f(-t)[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\; g(t) \propto f(t) \text{ if }f(t) \text{ is even.}[/latex]

options.A: g(t) would always be proportional to f (t)
options.B: g(t) would be proportional to f(t) if f(t) is an even function
options.C: g(t) would be proportional to f(t) only if f(t) is a sinusoidal function
options.D: g(t) would never be proportional to f(t)

question: Question 87 Let [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}}[/latex]  be the Z -transform of a causal signal x [n]. Then, the values of x[2] and x[3] are
solution: [latex]X(z)=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}}[/latex] From z-transform defination, [latex]\begin{aligned} X(z)&=\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }x[n]z^{-n} \\ &=x(0)+x(1)z^{-1}+x(2)z^{-2}+... \\ X(z)&=\frac{1}{1-z^{-3}} \\ &=1+0\cdot z^{-1}+0\cdot z^{-2}+... \end{aligned}[/latex] By comparision x(2)=0 and x(3)=1.

question: Question 91 x(t) is nonzero only for [latex]T_x \lt t \lt T'_x[/latex], and similarly, y(t) is nonzero only for [latex]T_y \lt t \lt T'_y[/latex]. Let z(t) be convolution of x(t) and y(t). Which one of the following statements is TRUE ?
solution: [latex]x(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_x \lt t \lt T'_x[/latex] and [latex]y(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_y \lt t \lt T'_y[/latex] [latex]\because \;\; z(t)=x(t)\otimes y(t)[/latex] then the limits of the resultant signal is [latex]T_x+T_y \lt t \lt T'_x+T'_y[/latex] i.e.  [latex]z(t)[/latex] is non-zero for [latex]T_x+T_y \lt t \lt T'_x+T'_y[/latex]

question: Question 92 Let [latex]X(s)=\frac{3s+5}{s^{2}+10s+21}[/latex] be the Laplace Transform of a signal x(t). Then, x([latex]0^+[/latex]) is
solution: Given,  [latex]X(s)=\left [ \frac{3s+5}{s^2+10s+21} \right ][/latex] Using initial value theorem, [latex]\begin{aligned} x(0^+) &= \lim_{s \to \infty }[sX(s)]\\ x(0^+) &= \lim_{s \to \infty } \left [ \frac{s(3s+5)}{s^2+10+21} \right ] \\ &= \lim_{s \to \infty }\left [ \frac{3+\frac{5}{s}}{1+\frac{10}{s}+\frac{21}{s^2}} \right ]=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 93 The impulse response of a continuous time system is given by [latex]h(t)=\delta(t-1) \delta (t-3)[/latex] . The value of the step response at t=2 is
solution: For step response, impulse response can be integrated. [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=u(t-1)+u(t-3)\\ y(2)&=u(1)+u(-1)\\ &=1+0=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 The impulse response of a system is h(t)=tu(t). For an input u(t-1), the output is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} h(t) &=tu(t) \\ H(s) &=\frac{1}{s^2} \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{Y(s)}{U(s)} &=\frac{1}{s^2} \\ Y(s) &=\frac{1}{s^2} \frac{e^{-s}}{s}\\ \Rightarrow \; y(t) &=\frac{(t-1)^2}{2}u(t-1) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 100 The input x(t) and output y(t) of a system are related as [latex]y(t)=\int^{t}_{-\infty }x(\tau ) cos (3\tau )d\tau[/latex]. The system is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y&=\int_{-\infty }^{t}x{\tau } \cos (3\tau )d\tau \\ y(t-t_0)&=\int_{-\infty }^{t-t_0}x{\tau } \cos (3\tau )d\tau\\ y(t) & \text{ for input }x(t-t_0) \text{ is}\\ y'(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{t}x{\tau -t_0} \cos (3\tau )d\tau\\ y'(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{t-t_0}x{\tau} \cos 3(\tau +t_0 )d\tau\\ y'(t) &\neq y(t-t_0) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, system is not time invariant for input [latex]x{\tau } =\cos (3\tau )[/latex] bounded input [latex]y(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{t} \cos ^2 (3\tau )d\tau \rightarrow \infty \; as \; t \rightarrow \infty[/latex] So, for bounded input, output is not bounded therefore system is not stable.

question: Question 101 The Fourier transform of a signal h(t) is [latex]H(j \omega)=(2\cos\omega)(\sin 2 \omega)/\omega[/latex]. The value of h(0) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H(j\omega )&=\cos \omega \cdot \frac{2 \sin 2\omega }{\omega }\\ &=\frac{e^{j\omega}+e^{-j\omega}}{2}\cdot \frac{2 \sin 2\omega }{\omega }\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left [ e^{j\omega}\left ( \frac{2 \sin 2\omega }{\omega } \right )+e^{-j\omega}\left ( \frac{2 \sin 2\omega }{\omega } \right ) \right ]\\ \text{Let, }X(\omega )&=\frac{2 \sin 2\omega }{\omega } \\ \text{Then, }x(t)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 & -2 \lt t \lt 2\\ 0 & \text{ otherwise} \end{matrix}\right. \\ &\text{By time shifting property}\\ h(t)&=\frac{1}{2}(x(t+1)+x(t-1))\\ \therefore \; h(0)&=\frac{1}{2}[x(1)+x(-1)]=\frac{1}{2}[1+1]=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 Consider the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}y(t)}{dt^{2}}+2\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+y(t)=\delta (t)[/latex] with [latex]y(t)|_{t=0^{-}}=-2[/latex] and [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}|_{t=0^{-}}=0[/latex] The numerical value of [latex]\frac{dy}{dt}|_{t=0^{+}}[/latex], is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\frac{d^2y(t)}{dt^2}+2\frac{dy(t)}{dt}+y(t)=\delta (t)\\ &\Rightarrow \; s^2y(s)-sy(0)-y'(0)+2[sy(s)-y(0)]\\&+y(s)=1\\ &\Rightarrow \; y(s)[s^22s+1]-(s \times -2)-y(0)\\&-(2 \times -2)=1\\ &\Rightarrow \; y(s)[s^2+2a+1]=-2s-3\\ &\Rightarrow \;y(s)=\frac{-2s-3}{s^2+2s+1}=\frac{-2}{s+1}-\frac{1}{(s+1)^2}\\ &\Rightarrow \; y(t)=-2e^{-t}-te^{-t}\\ &\frac{dy(t)}{dt}=2e^{-t}-(-te^{-t}+e^{-t})\\ &\frac{dy(t)}{dt}=e^{-t}+te^{-t}\\ &\frac{dy(t)}{dt}|_{t=0^+}=1+0=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 Let y[n] denote the convolution of h[n] and g[n], where h[n]=[latex](1/2)^{n}[/latex]u[n] and g[n] is a causal sequence. If y[0]=1 and y[1]=1/2, then g[1] equals
solution: Given, g[n] is causal sequence Therefore, g[n] will be zero for [latex] n \lt 0[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y[n]&=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty }g[k]h[n-k]\\ h[n]&=\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )^n u[n]\\ h[n]&=\left\{\begin{matrix} \left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )^n \; ;& n\geq 0\\ 0& n \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ h[0]&=0, h[1]=\frac{1}{2}, h[2]=\frac{1}{4}\\ y[0]&=g[0] h[0]+g[1]h[-1]+...\\ 1&=g[0] \times 1+0+0+...\\ g[0]&=1\\ y[1]&=g[0]h[1]+g[1]h[0]+g[2]h[-1]+...\\ \frac{1}{2}&=1\cdot \frac{1}{2}+g[1]\cdot 1+0\\ \Rightarrow \;g[1]&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 104 The unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]f(t)[/latex] is [latex]\frac{1}{s^{2}+s+1}[/latex]. The unilateral Laplace transform of [latex]tf(t)[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{If }L[f(t)]&=\bar{f}(s)\\ \text{then, }L[t^nf(t)]&=(-1)^n\frac{d^n}{ds^n}\bar{f}(s)\\ &\text{In this problem,}\\ \text{Given, }L[f(t)]&=\frac{1}{s^2+s+1}=\bar{f}(s)\\ &\text{We need,}\\ L[tf(t)]&=(-1)^n\frac{d^1}{ds^1}\bar{f}(s)\\ &=-\frac{d}{ds}\bar{f}(s)\\ &=-\frac{d}{ds}\left [ \frac{1}{s^2+s+1} \right ]\\ &=-\left [ \frac{-1}{(s^2+s+1)^2} \right ] \times (2s+1)\\ &=\frac{2s+1}{(s^2+s+1)^2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 If [latex]x[n] = (1/3)^{|n|}-(1/2)^{n} u[n][/latex], then the region of convergence (ROC) of its Z-transform in the Z-plane will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Let, }x_1[n]&=\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )^{|n|}\\ \text{and }x_2[n]&=\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )^{n} u[n]\\ \Rightarrow \; x_1[n]&=\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )^{n}u[n]+\left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )^{-n} u[-n-1]\\ \left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )^{n} u[n] & \overset{z}{\leftrightarrow} \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{3}z^{-1}}; \; ROC: |z| \gt \frac{1}{3}\\ \left ( \frac{1}{3} \right )^{-n} u[-n-1] & \overset{z}{\leftrightarrow} \frac{-1}{1-\left (\frac{1}{3} \right )^{-1}z^{-1}}; \; ROC: |z| \lt 3\\ \text{and } x_2[n]=\left ( \frac{1}{2} \right )^{n} u[n] & \overset{z}{\leftrightarrow} \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{2}z^{-1}}; \; ROC: |z| \gt \frac{1}{2}\\ \therefore \; & \text{ROC is }\frac{1}{2} \lt |z| \lt 3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 107 Let the Laplace transform of a function F(t) which exists for [latex]t \gt 0 \; be \; F_1(s)[/latex]
and the Laplace transform of its delayed version [latex]f(t-\tau ) \; be \; F_{2}(s)[/latex]. Let [latex]F_1^*(s)[/latex] be the complex conjugate of [latex]F_1(s)[/latex] with the Laplace variable set [latex]s=\sigma +i \omega[/latex]. If [latex]G(s)=\frac{F_{2}(s)F_{1}^*(s)}{|F_{1}(s)|^{2}}[/latex], then the inverse Laplace transform of G(s) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F_2(t)&=L(f(t-\tau ))=e^{-s\tau }F_1(s)\\ G(s)&=\frac{e^{-s\tau }F_1(s)F_1^*(s)}{|F_1(s)|^2}=e^{-s\tau }\\ G(t)&=\delta (t-\tau ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.D: An ideal delayed step function u[latex](t-\tau )[/latex]

question: Question 108 Given two continuous time signals  [latex]x(t) =e^{-t}[/latex] and  [latex]y(t) =e^{-2t}[/latex] which exist for [latex]t \gt 0[/latex], the convolution z(t)=x(t)*y(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(s)&=\frac{1}{s+1} \\ y(s)&=\frac{1}{s+2} \\ z(s)&=x(s)\cdot y(s) \\ &=\frac{1}{s+1} \times \frac{1}{s+2} \\ &=\frac{1}{s+1} - \frac{1}{s+2} \\ z(t)&=e^{-t}-e^{-2t} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 110 Given f(t) and g(t)as shown below: The Laplace transform of g(t) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g(t) &=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 &3 \lt t \lt 5 \\ 0& t \lt 3, t \gt 5 \end{matrix}\right. \\ \Rightarrow \; g(t) &=u(t-3)-u(t-5) \\ L(g(t))&=L(u(t-3))-L(u(t-5)) \\ &= \frac{1}{s}e^{-3s}-\frac{1}{s}e^{-5s}\\ &= \frac{1}{s}(e^{-3s}-e^{-5s})\\ &= \frac{e^{-3s}}{s}(1-e^{-2s}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 111 Given f(t) and g(t)as shown below: g(t) can be expressed as

question:
Question 112 Given the finite length input x[n] and the corresponding finite length output y[n]
of an LTI system as shown below, the impulse response h[n] of the system is
solution: x[n] = { 1 , -1}, M=2 y[n] = { 1 ,0,0,0,-1}, [latex]N_1=5[/latex] Since, output hasnumber of elements [latex]N_1=M+N-1[/latex] where N is number of elements in impulse response h[n]. [latex]\therefore \;\; 5=2+N-1[/latex] [latex]N=4[/latex] Let it be [latex]a_1,a_2,b_1,b_2[/latex] [latex]y[n]=[a_1,(a_2-a_1), (b_1-a_2), (b_2-b_1), -b_2][/latex] Comaparing with [latex]y[n]=1, 0,0,0,-1] [/latex] [latex]a_1=1[/latex] [latex]a_2=a_1=1[/latex] [latex]b_1=a_1=1[/latex] [latex]b_2=b_1=1[/latex] Therefore, [latex]h[n]=\{1,1,1,1 \}[/latex]

question:
Question 113 x(t) is a positive rectangular pulse from t=-1 to t=+1 with unit height as
shown in the figure. The value of [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }|X(\omega )|^{2}d\omega[/latex] {where [latex]X(\omega )[/latex] is the Fourier transform of x(t)} is.
solution: By using Parseval's theorem, [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }|X(\omega )|^2 d\omega &= 2 \pi \int_{-1}^{1}1 \; dt=2 \pi \times 2\\ \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }|X(\omega )|^2 d\omega &=4 \pi \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 115 The system represented by the input-output relationship [latex]y(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{5t}x(\tau )d\tau , \; t\gt0[/latex]

question: Question 117 The Fourier Series coefficients of a periodic signal x(t), expressed as [latex]x(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty }^{\infty }a_{k}e^{j2 \pi kt/T}[/latex] are given by [latex]a_{-2}=2-j1[/latex], [latex]a_{-1}=0.5+j0.2[/latex], [latex]a_{0}=j2[/latex], [latex]a_{1}=0.5-j0.2[/latex], [latex]a_{2}=2+j1[/latex] and [latex]a_{k}=0[/latex] for [latex]|k| \gt 2[/latex] Which of the following is true ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=a_{-2}e^{-j2\omega _0t}+a_{-1}e^{-j\omega _0t}\\ &+a_{1}e^{j\omega _0t} +a_{2}e^{j2\omega _0t}\\ &=(2-j)e^{-j2\omega _0t}+(2+j)e^{j2\omega _0t}\\ &+(0.5+j0.2)e^{-j\omega _0t}+(0.5-j0.2)e^{j\omega _0t}+2j\\ &=2(e^{-j2\omega _0t}+e^{j2\omega _0t})+j(e^{j2\omega _0t}-e^{-j2\omega _0t})\\ &+0.5(e^{j\omega _0t}+e^{-j\omega _0t})-j0.2(e^{j\omega _0t}-e^{-j\omega _0t})+2j\\ &=4 \cos 2\omega _0t-2 \sin 2\omega _0t+ \cos \omega _0t \\ &+0.4 \sin \omega _0t+2j\\ &=\text{Real}[x(t)]+j\text{Img}[x(t)]\\ &\text{where,}\\ \text{Real}[x(t)]&=4 \cos 2\omega _0t-2 \sin 2\omega _0t+ \cos \omega _0t \\ &+0.4 \sin \omega _0t\\ &= \text{neither even nor odd signal}\\ \text{Img}[x(t)]&=2=\text{constant} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: x(t) has finite energy because only finitely many coefficients are non-zero
options.B: x(t) has zero average value because it is periodic
options.C: The imaginary part of x(t) is constant
options.D: The real part of x(t) is even

question:
Question 118 A cascade of three Linear Time Invariant systems is causal and unstable. From
this, we conclude that
solution: Since in cascade overall impulse response [latex]h(t)=h_1(t)*h_2(t)*h_3(t)[/latex] [latex]h_1(t),h_2(t),h_3(t)[/latex] are impulse response of individual systems. Since, initial point where h(t) is nonzero is [latex]t \geq 0[/latex] and since in convolution initial point [latex]=t_1+t_2+t_3[/latex] where, [latex]t_1,t_2,t_3[/latex] are initial point of [latex]h_1(t), h_2(t),h_3(t)[/latex] respectively. So for it to be greater than or equal to zero at least one of them [latex]t_1, t_2\; or \; t_3[/latex] must be +ve i.e. greater than zero so atleast one of them must be causal. Similarly if one (atleast) of the system become unstable then overall system will become unstable.

options.A: each system in the cascade is individually causal and unstable
options.B: at least on system is unstable and at least one system is causal
options.C: at least one system is causal and all systems are unstable
options.D: the majority are unstable and the majority are causal

question:
Question 119 A Linear Time Invariant system with an impulse response h(t) produces output
y(t) when input x(t) is applied. When the input x(t-[latex]\tau[/latex]) is applied to a system with impulse response h(t-[latex]\tau[/latex]), the output will be
solution: Case-1: [latex] Y(s)=H(s) \cdot X(s)[/latex] Case-1: input [latex]=x(t-\tau )\Rightarrow X(s)e^{-s\tau }[/latex] impulse response [latex]=h(t-\tau )\Rightarrow H(s)e^{-s\tau }[/latex] Output: [latex]Y'(s)=X(s)e^{-s\tau }H(s)e^{-s\tau }[/latex] [latex]Y'(s)=X(s)H(s)e^{-2s\tau }=Y(s)e^{-2s\tau}[/latex] [latex]y'(t)=y(t-2 \tau)[/latex]

question: Question 120 Let [latex]x(t)= rect(t-\frac{1}{2}[/latex]) (where [latex]rect(x) = 1[/latex] for [latex]-\frac{1}{2}\leq x\leq \frac{1}{2}[/latex] and zero otherwise. Then if [latex]sinc(x)=\frac{sin(\pi x)}{\pi x}[/latex], the Fourier Transform of [latex]x(t) + x(-t)[/latex] will be given by
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
x(t)&= \text{rect}[t-1/2]\\
x(t)&=1 \;\;\;0\leq t\leq 1\\
    &=0 \;\;\; \text{otherwise}\\
F[x(t)]&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }x(t)e^{-j\omega t}dt\\
&=\int_{0}^{1}1e^{-j\omega t}dt=\frac{1}{j\omega }(1-e^{-j\omega })\\
&=\frac{2}{\omega }\left [ \frac{e^{j\omega t} -e^{-j\omega /2}}{2j} \right ]xe^{-j\omega /2}\\
&=\frac{\sin \omega /2}{\omega /2}\cdot e^{-j\omega /2}\\
F[x(t)+x(-t)]&\overset{F.T.}{\rightarrow}X(\omega )+X(-\omega )\\
&=\frac{\sin \omega /2}{\omega /2}[ e^{-j\omega /2}+e^{j\omega /2}]\\
&=\frac{\sin \omega /2}{\omega /2} 2 \cos \frac{\omega }{2}\\
&=2 \sin c\left ( \frac{\omega }{2 \pi} \right ) \cos \left ( \frac{\omega }{2} \right ) 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 Given [latex]X(z)=\frac{z}{(z-a)^2}[/latex] with [latex]|z| \gt a[/latex], the residue of [latex]X(z)z^{n-1}[/latex] at z=a for [latex]n\geq 0[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(z)&=\frac{z}{(z-a)^2}\\ \therefore \; z^{n-1}X(z)&=\frac{z^n}{(z-a)^2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Since, z-a is a pole of second order, therefore residue at z=a [latex]=\frac{d}{dz}\left [ (z-a)^2 \frac{z^n}{(z-a)^2}\right ]_{at\; z=a}=[nz^n-1]_{z=a}=na^{n-1}[/latex]

question: Question 122 H(z) is a transfer function of a real system. When a signal [latex]x[n] =(1+j)^{n}[/latex] is the input to such a system, the output is zero. Further, the Region of convergence (ROC) of [latex](1-\frac{1}{2}z^{-1})[/latex]H(z) is the entire Z-plane (except z = 0). It can then be inferred that H(z) can have a minimum of

Question 123 Let x(t) be a periodic signal with time period T, Let [latex]y(t)=x(t-t_0)+x(t+t_0)[/latex]
for some [latex]t_0[/latex]. The Fourier Series coefficients of y(t) are denoted by [latex]b_k[/latex]. If [latex]b_k=0[/latex] for
all odd k , then [latex]t_0[/latex] can be equal to
solution: [latex]y(t)=x(t-t_0)+x(t+x_0)[/latex] Since, [latex]x(t)[/latex] is periodic with period T. Therefore, [latex]x(t-t_0)[/latex] and [latex]x(t+t_0)[/latex] will also  be periodic with period T. [latex]\therefore \; b_k=a_ke^{-jk\omega _0t_0}+a_ke^{jk\omega _0t_0}[/latex] [latex]a_k [/latex] is Fourier series coefficient of signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] therefore, [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; b_k&=a_k(e^{-jk\omega _0t_0}+e^{jk\omega _0t_0}) \\ b_k&=2a_k \cos k\omega _0t_0 \\ \text{since, }b_k &=0 \text{ for odd k} \\ \text{i.e. } k\omega _0t_0&=k\frac{\pi}{2}\\ \text{ where } k&=\pm 1,\pm 3,\pm 5... \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \omega _0t_0 &=\frac{\pi}{2} \\ t_0&=\frac{\pi}{2} \times \frac{T}{2 \pi}=\frac{T}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 A signal [latex]x(t)=sinc(\alpha t)[/latex] where [latex]\alpha[/latex] is a real constant [latex](sinc(x)=\frac{sin (\pi x)}{\pi x})[/latex] is the input to a Linear Time Invariant system whose impulse response [latex]h(t)=sinc(\beta t)[/latex], where [latex]\beta[/latex] is a real constant. If min[latex](\alpha ,\beta )[/latex] denotes the minimum of [latex]\alpha \;and \; \beta [/latex] and similarly, max[latex](\alpha ,\beta )[/latex] denotes the maximum of [latex]\alpha \; and \; \beta [/latex], and K is a constant, which one of the following statements is true about the output of the system ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=\sin c (\alpha t)=Sa[\pi \alpha t]\\ h(t)&=\sin c (\beta t)=Sa[\pi \beta t]\\ x(t)&=Sa[\pi \alpha t] \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=h(t)*x(t)\\ Y(j\omega )&=X(j\omega )H(j\omega ) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=\frac{1}{\beta }Sa( \pi \alpha t)\;\;\; if \; \alpha \lt \beta \\ y(t)&=\frac{1}{\beta } \sin c(\alpha t)\;\;\; if \; \alpha \lt \beta \\ y(t)&=\frac{1}{\alpha }\sin c( \beta t)\;\;\; if \; \alpha \gt \beta \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] So, output is of the form [latex]k \sin c (\gamma t)[/latex] where,  [latex]\gamma =min(\alpha ,\beta )[/latex]

options.A: It will be of the form Ksinc([latex]\gamma[/latex]t) where [latex]\gamma[/latex] = min[latex](\alpha ,\beta )[/latex]
options.B: It will be of the form Ksinc([latex]\gamma[/latex]t) where [latex]\gamma[/latex] = max[latex](\alpha ,\beta )[/latex]
options.C: It will be of the form Ksinc([latex]\alpha[/latex]t)
options.D: It can not be a sinc type of signal

question: Question 125 A system with x(t) and output y(t) is defined by the input-output relation : [latex]y(t)=\int_{-\infty }^{-2t}x(\tau)d\tau[/latex] The system will be
solution: First of all we will check for causality, [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{-2t}x(\tau ) d\tau \\ \text{So for }t&=2 \\ y(-2)&=\int_{-\infty }^{4}x(\tau ) d\tau \end{aligned}[/latex] So, output depends on future values of input along with past and present values of input, so system is non-casual. Let us find output for shifted input [latex]x(t-t_0)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{-2t}x(\tau -t_0) d\tau \\ y'(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{2(t-t_0)}x(\tau ) d\tau\;\;...(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, shift the output by [latex]t_0[/latex] then, [latex]y(t-t_0)=\int_{-\infty }^{2(t-t_0)}x(\tau ) d\tau \;\;...(ii)[/latex] so from eq. (i) and (ii), [latex] y'(t) \neq y(t-t_0)[/latex] Therefore system is time varient. Non-causal and time variant is present only in option (D).

question:
Question 126 Given a sequence x[n], to generate the sequence y[n]=x[3-4n], which one of the
following procedures would be correct ?
solution: [latex]y[n]=x[3-4n]=x[-4n+3][/latex] So to obtain [latex]y[n][/latex], we first advance [latex]x[n][/latex] by 3 unit. i.e.  [latex]z_1[n]=x[n+3][/latex] Now we will take every fourth sample of [latex]z_1[n][/latex] i.e.   [latex]z_2[n]=z_1[4n]=x[4n+3][/latex] Now reverse (time reverse) [latex]z_2[n][/latex] will give [latex]y[n]=z_2[-n]=x[-4n+3][/latex]

options.A: First delay x[n] by 3 samples to generate [latex]z_{1}[n][/latex], then pick every [latex]4^{th}[/latex] sample of [latex]z_{1}[n][/latex] to generate [latex]z_{2}[n][/latex], and than finally time reverse [latex]z_{2}[n][/latex] to obtain y[n].
options.B: First advance x[n] by 3 samples to generate [latex]z_{1}[n][/latex], then pick every [latex]4^{th}[/latex] sample of [latex]z_{1}[n][/latex] to generate [latex]z_{2}[n][/latex], and then finally time reverse [latex]z_{2}[n][/latex] to obtain y[n]
options.C: First pick every fourth sample of x[n] to generate [latex]v_{1}[n][/latex], time-reverse [latex]v_{1}[n][/latex] to obtain [latex]v_{2}[n][/latex], and finally advance [latex]v_{2}[n][/latex] by 3 samples to obtain y[n]
options.D: First pick every fourth sample of x[n] to generate [latex]v_{1}[n][/latex], time-reverse [latex]v_{1}[n][/latex] to obtain [latex]v_{2}[n][/latex], and finally delay [latex]v_{2}[n][/latex] by 3 samples to obtain y[n]

question:
Question 127 The impulse response of a causal linear time-invariant system is given as h(t).
Now consider the following two statements : Statement (I): Principle of superposition holds Statement (II): h(t)=0 for [latex]t \lt 0[/latex] Which one of the following statements is correct ?
solution: Since, system is casual therefore its impulse response will be zero for [latex]t \lt 0[/latex]. So, statement-II is correct. Since, system is linear, it also satisfies the principle of superposition. So, both the statements are correct.

options.A: Statements (I) is correct and statement (II) is wrong
options.B: Statements (II) is correct and statement (I) is wrong
options.C: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are wrong
options.D: Both Statement (I) and Statement (II) are correct

question: Question 128 A signal [latex]e^{-\alpha t}sin(\omega t)[/latex] is the input to a real Linear Time Invariant system. Given K and [latex]\phi[/latex] are constants, the output of the system will be of the form [latex]Ke^{-\beta t}sin(vt+\phi )[/latex] where

question:
Question 129 A signal is processed by a causal filter with transfer function G(s). [latex]G(z)=\alpha z^{-1}+\beta z^{-3}[/latex] is a low pass digital filter with a phase characteristics same as
that of the above question if
solution: [latex]G(z)=\alpha z^{-1}+\beta z^{-3}[/latex] For, low frequency [latex](z=1)\rightarrow G(1)=\alpha +\beta \;\;...(i)[/latex] For, high frequency [latex](z=-1)\rightarrow G(-1)=-(\alpha +\beta) \;\;...(ii)[/latex] For now, [latex]g(n)=\{0,\alpha ,0, \beta\}[/latex] For linear phase FIR filter, g(n) should be either even symmetric or odd symmetric about virtual y-axis. To, satisfy the above condition. CASE: (i) [latex]\alpha =- \beta[/latex] ( odd symmetric about virtual y-axis) But in this case, G(1)=G(-1)=0 i.e. at low frequency [latex]\Rightarrow \; G(z)=0[/latex] and at high frequency [latex]\Rightarrow \; G(z)=0[/latex] Thus in this case filter will be band-pass. CASE: (ii) [latex]\alpha = \beta[/latex] ( even symmetric about virtual y-axis) In this case, At low frequency [latex]\Rightarrow \; G(z)=2\alpha [/latex] and at high frequency [latex]\Rightarrow \; G(-1)=-2\alpha [/latex] Filter will be either all pass or band-stop. Now, [latex]\begin{aligned} G(e^{j\omega })&=\alpha (e^{-j\omega }+e^{-j 3 \omega }) \\ &=\alpha e^{-j2\omega }(e^{j\omega }+e^{-j\omega }) \\ &= 2\alpha e^{-j2\omega } \cos \omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 A signal is processed by a causal filter with transfer function G(s). For a distortion free output signal wave form, G(s) must

options.A: provides zero phase shift for all frequency
options.B: provides constant phase shift for all frequency
options.C: provides linear phase shift that is proportional to frequency
options.D: provides a phase shift that is inversely proportional to frequency

question: Question 131 [latex]X(z) = 1 - 3z^{-1}[/latex], [latex]Y(z) = 1 + 2z^{-2}[/latex] are Z transforms of two signals x[n],y[n] respectively. A linear time invariant system has the impulse response h[n] defined by these two signals as h[n] = x[n-1] * y[n] where * denotes discrete time convolution. Then the output of the system for the input [latex]\delta[/latex][n-1]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(z)&=(1-3z^{-1})\\ Y(z)&=(1+2z^{-2})\\ h[n]&=x(n-1)*y[n]\\ \Rightarrow \; H[z]&=z^{-1}X(z)\cdot Y(z)\\ \Rightarrow \; H[z]&=z^{-1}(1-3z^{-1})(1+2z^{-2})\\ \Rightarrow \; H[z]&=z^{-1}(1+2z^{-2}-3z^{-1}-6z^{-3})\\ \Rightarrow \; H[z]&=(z^{-1}-3z^{-2}+2z^{-3}-6z^{-4})\\ &\text{when input,}\\ I(n)&=\delta [n-1]\; \text{ then }, I[z]=z^{-1}\\ &\text{Therefore output,}\\ P(n)&=h[n]*I[n]\\ \Rightarrow \; P(z)&=H(z)I(z)\\ P(z)&=(z^{-1}-3z^{-2}+2z^{-3}-6z^{-4}) \times z^{-1}\\ P(z)&=z^{-2}-3z^{-3}+2z^{-4}-6z^{-5}\\ \therefore \; P(z)&=\delta [n-2]-3\delta [n-3]\\&+2\delta [n-4]-6\delta [n-5] \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.D: does not satisfy any of the above three

question:
Question 132 If u(t), r(t) denote the unit step and unit ramp functions respectively and
u(t)*r(t) their convolution, then the function u(t+1)*r(t-2) is given by
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
u(t+1)*r(t-1)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }r(\tau -2)u(t+1-\tau )d\tau \\
z(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{(t+1)}r(\tau -2)d\tau \\
z(t)&=\int_{2}^{(t+1)}r(\tau -2)d\tau \\
\text{For, }(t+1)& \geq 2\\
z(t)&=\left ( \frac{\tau ^2}{2}-2\tau  \right )_2^{(t+1)}\\
&=\frac{1}{2}[\tau ^2-4\tau ]_2^{(t+1)}\\
\text{For, }t \geq 1&=\frac{1}{2}[(t+1)^2-4(t+1)-4+8]\\
z(t)&=\frac{1}{2}[t^2+2t+1-4t-4+4]\\
\text{For, }t &\geq 1\\
z(t)&=\frac{1}{2}(t-1)^2\\
\text{For, }t &\geq 1\\
\Rightarrow \; z(t)&=\frac{1}{2}(t-1)^2u(t-1)
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 133 A signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is given by [latex]x(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1, & -T/4 \lt  t \leq 3T/4\\ -1, & 3T/4 \lt t\leq 7T/4\\ -x(t-T) &  \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Which among the following gives the fundamental fourier term of x(t)?
solution:
According to defination of signal given in question the x(t) will be as So it is periodic with period, [latex]T_0=\frac{7T}{4}-\left ( -\frac{T}{4} \right )=2T[/latex] Therefore, fundamental angular frequency [latex]\omega _0=\frac{2 \pi}{T_0}=\frac{2 \pi}{2T}=\frac{\pi}{T}[/latex] Now, [latex]C_1=[/latex] (exponential series coefficient for k=1) [latex]\begin{aligned}
C_1 &=\frac{1}{T_0}\int _{T_0}x(t)e^{-j\omega _0t}dt \\ 
C_1 &=\frac{1}{T_0}\left [ \int_{-T/4}^{3T/4} e^{-j\omega _0t}dt+\int_{3T/4}^{7T/4} -1e^{-j\omega _0t}dt \right ] \\ 
C_1 &=\frac{1}{j 2\pi}[2e^{j\pi/4}+2e^{j\pi/4}] \\ 
 C_1&=\frac{2}{j\pi}e^{j\pi/4}=\frac{2}{\pi}e^{-j\pi/4} =\frac{2}{\pi}\left ( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{j}{\sqrt{2}} \right )\\ 
 &\text{Comparing it with} \\ 
C_1 &=\frac{a_1}{2}-\frac{jb_1}{2} \\ 
 a_1&=\frac{4}{\sqrt{2}\pi}, b_1=\frac{4}{\sqrt{2}\pi} \\ 
\therefore \; & \text{fundamental fourier term will be}\\ 
 &= a_1 \cos \omega _0 t+b_1 \sin \omega _0 t \\ 
 &= \frac{4}{\sqrt{2}\pi} \cos \left ( \frac{\pi}{T}t \right )+\frac{4}{\sqrt{2}\pi} \sin \left ( \frac{\pi}{T}t \right )\\ 
 &=\frac{4}{\pi}\cos \left [\frac{\pi}{T}t-\frac{\pi}{4}  \right ]
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 Consider the discrete-time system shown in the figure where the impulse response of G(z) is g(0)=0, g(1)=g(2)=1, g(3)=g(4)=...= 0 This system is stable for range of values of K
solution: Given: [latex]g(1)=g(2)=1[/latex] i.e.  [latex]g[n]=\delta [n-1]+\delta [n-2][/latex] Therefore, [latex]G(z)=z^{-1}+z^{-2}[/latex] Therefore overall transfer function of closed loop system, [latex]\begin{aligned} T(z)&=\frac{G(z)}{1-kG(z)} \\ &=\frac{z^{-1}+z^{-2}}{1-k(z^{-1}+z^{-2})} \\ &= \frac{z+1}{z^2-k(z+1)} \end{aligned}[/latex] So the system will be stable if it's outer most pole will lie inside the unit circle. Location of poles, [latex]\begin{aligned} z=\frac{+k\pm \sqrt{k^2+4k}}{2}\\ \frac{k+ \sqrt{k^2+4k}}{2} \lt 1\\ k+ \sqrt{k^2+4k} \lt 2\\ \sqrt{k^2+4k} \lt (2-k)\\ k^2+4k \lt (2-k)^2\\ k^2+4k \lt 4+k^2-4k\\ 8k \lt 4\\ k \lt \frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 135 The frequency spectrum of a signal is shown in the figure. If this is ideally sampled
at intervals of 1 ms, then the frequency spectrum of the sampled signal will be

question:

Question 140 The discrete-time signal [latex]x[n]\leftrightarrow X(z)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }\frac{3^{n}}{2+n}z^{2n},[/latex] where [latex]\leftrightarrow[/latex] denotes a
transform-pair relationship, is orthogonal to the signal
solution: [latex]x(n)\rightleftharpoons X(z)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }\frac{3^n}{2+n}z^{2n}[/latex] In X(z), power of z are even. Therefore, samples in x(n) are available at even instant of time. By observing all the options. Option (B): [latex]y_2(n)\rightleftharpoons Y_2(z)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }(5^n-n)z^{-(2n+1)}[/latex] In [latex]y_2(z)[/latex], powers of z are odd. Therefore, samples in [latex]y_2(n)[/latex] are avialable only at odd instant of time. Hence, [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }x(n)\cdot y_2(n)=0[/latex] Thus, [latex]x(n)[/latex] is orthogonal to [latex]y_2(n)[/latex].

Question 143 x(t) is a real valued function of a real variable with period T. Its trigonometric
Fourier Series expansion contains no terms of frequency [latex]\omega = 2\pi[/latex](2k)/T;  k=1,2...  Also, no sine terms are present. Then x(t) satisfies the equation
solution: Since trigonometric fourier series has no sine terms and has only cosine terms therefore this will be an even signal i.e. it will satisfy. [latex]x(t)=x(-t)[/latex] or, we can write, [latex]x(t-T)=x(-t+T)[/latex] but signal is periodic with period T. therefore [latex]x(t-T)=x(t)[/latex] therefore,  [latex]x(t)=x(T-t)\;\;...(i)[/latex] Now, since signal contains only odd harmonics i.e. no terms of frequency [latex]\omega =\frac{2 \pi \times 2k}{T},\;\;\;k=1,2,3,4[/latex] i.e. no even harmonics. This means signal contains half wave symmetry this implies that, [latex]x(t)=-x\left ( t-\frac{T}{2} \right )\;\;...(ii)[/latex] From eq. (i) and (ii), [latex]x(t)=x(T-t)=-x\left ( t-\frac{T}{2} \right )[/latex]

question: Question 145 If u(t) is the unit step and [latex]\delta \left ( t \right )[/latex] is the unit impulse function, the inverse z-transform of F(z)=[latex]\frac{1}{z+1}[/latex] for [latex]k\gt 0[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F(z) &=1-\frac{z}{z+1} \\ &= 1-\frac{1}{1+z^{-1}}\\ &= \delta (k)-(-1)^k u(k) \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 148 For the triangular wave from shown in the figure, the RMS value of the voltage
is equal to
solution: From the wave symmetry, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{rms}&=\left [ \frac{1}{T}\left ( \int_{0}^{T/2}\left ( \frac{2t}{T} \right )^2dt+\int_{T/2}^{T}0dt \right ) \right ]^{1/2} \\ V_{rms}^2 &=\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T/2}\frac{4t^2}{T^2}=\frac{4}{3T^3}\left ( \frac{T^3}{8} \right ) =\frac{1}{6}\\ \therefore \; V_{rms} &=\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}} V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 149 The rms value of the periodic waveform given in figure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{rms} &=\left [ \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T}i^2(t) \right ]^{1/2} \\ \therefore \; I^2_{rms} &=\left [ \frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T/2}\left ( -\frac{12t}{T} \right )^2 dt+\frac{1}{T}\int_{T/2}^{T}6^2 dt \right ] \\ &= \left [\frac{1}{T}\int_{0}^{T/2}\frac{144t^2}{T^2}dt+\frac{36}{T}\int_{T/2}^{T}dt \right ]\\ &=\frac{144}{T^3}\left [ \frac{t^3}{2} \right ]_0^{T/2}+\frac{36}{T}\left [ \frac{T}{2} \right ] \\ &=\frac{144}{8 \times 3}+\frac{36}{2}=24 \\ \therefore \; I_{rms} &= 2\sqrt{6}A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 156 Given the relationship between the input u(t) and the output y(t) to be [latex]y(t)=\int_{0}^{t}(2+t-\tau )e^{-3(t-\tau )}u(\tau )d\tau[/latex], the transfer function Y(s)/U(s) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(t)&=\int_{0}^{t}(2+t-\tau )e^{-3(t-\tau )} u(\tau )d\tau \\ y(t)&=[(2+t)e^{-3t}]\times u(t) \\ \therefore \; H(s)&=\frac{2}{s+3}+\frac{1}{(s+3)^2} \\ \therefore \; T.F.&=H(s)=\frac{2s+7}{(s+3)^2} \end{aligned}[/latex]
